awd_titl_txt: Kickstarting Advances in Assistive and Rehabilitative Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
Overview: A virtual workshop on the topic of assistive and rehabilitative technologies for persons with disabilities or impairments will be conducted The main objective of the workshop is to understand the existing landscape of research, development, and practice for these technologies and how they promote better and healthier living for persons with disabilities or impairments. Building on participant insights and expertise, the challenges and opportunities for convergence based research that’s inspired by users will be identified by workshop participants. They will engage with each other to answer several relevant questions regarding this landscape and to develop a framework for identifying investigations and initiatives ready for convergent acceleration. Inspired by grounded theory studies, the synthesized knowledge and identified categories will be fed back to the participants for further exploration and refinement. 
Intellectual Merit: The workshop aims to identify candidate research and translational gaps related to assistive and rehabilitative technologies. This will be made possible by bringing together a diverse group of stakeholders from academia, industry, other agencies, nonprofits and the users themselves. To provide a coherent structure to the workshop , the overall research area has been decomposed into the intervention type, the various populations with disabilities or impairments, and the enablers of the technological interventions. Participants and perspectives from across these classes will be invited. In bringing together professionals and people who would not normally comingle, the intent is to compare and contrast the different perspective to arrive at a holistic understanding of the field and answer the questions: What initiatives or innovations would most effectively address the most impactful needs of the various target populations.? Are these initiatives capable of resulting in a proof-of-concept deliverable within a 3-4 year period? These answers should identify some clear themes that need convergence and are ready for an accelerated delivery of some tangible outcomes.  

Broader Impacts: Beside the potential to seed new research collaborations, the work will connect researchers, practitioners, nonprofits and industry in some very unique partnerships. Secondly, the topic of investigation is one that touches on most members of society given the prevalence of disabilities or injury-related impairments within the population.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There were two goals, one being a research goal and one being a workshop goal. The research goal of the workshop was to understand the current research and product landscape of assistive and rehabilitative technologies for the disabled or impaired across the age spectrum. Its focus was on technologies that support daily living and understanding what perceptions different communities of interest had regarding these technologies and their development from research lab to commercial product. Best practice on how to achieve translation from research to product figured prominently in the workshop discussions. Especially with regards to the teaming required and the importance of involving people with disabilities in all aspects of the process.

The research goal supported the main workshop goal, to arrive at a draft Convergence Accelerator solicitation capable of inducing the right kind of convergent teams to propose research efforts fitting the Convergence Accelerator scope. Arriving at the draft solicitation established in what manner the chosen topic could best fit the scope of a Convergence Accelerator topic and what an acceptable description should contain.

The workshop had three phases focusing on recruitment, execution, and synthesis. The recruitment phase involved attracting a rich and diverse group of workshop participants spanning the anticipated user populations, researchers, industry professionals, clinicians or practitioners, funding agencies or organizations, and advocacy organizations. Emphasis was also on ensuring broad representation from people with disabilities or their caregivers. Roughly one-third of participants fit this category. The execution phase was designed to be a Grounded Theory study whereby the workshop participants contributed to and refined overall understanding regarding the draft program solicitation needs and themes. The synthesis phase involved drafting a potential solicitation and receiving participant feedback for the final draft version, followed by a final report communicating the execution and findings of the workshop.

The workshop conversations indicated that the type of research or technological development to be supported or promoted as part of a Convergence Accelerator project was less important than the approach taken. There was consensus on the importance of involving people with disabilities in as much of the process as possible, from conception to completion. There was also compelling evidence that involvement of ancillary users of the technology, from clinicians to caregivers, is also essential to long-term viability of any developed technology that required these user populations. The workshop group therefore, established a set of “conditions for success” that characterize what successful research and development of technologies meant to aid people with disabilities consists of.  

In the process, the participants also discussed some of the challenges of assistive technology, the role of machine learning and equitable yet anonymous data collection, and the role of virtual communities. Overall, it seemed like many areas were ready for translation, but that connecting several critical pieces were needed.  The convergence accelerator appeared to be an exceelent mechanism to force the connections. These discussions informed the general recommendation that the Convergence Accelerator should not focus on particular assistive technologies, but to consider more broadly several domains. The idea being that the different teams would be able to learn from each other as they proceeded, given that the Convergence Accelerator program uses a cohort model.

The entire process was designed to be as open and as accessible as possible. Participant talks were posted to a YouTube channel for viewing by others. All those seeking to be live participants were provided the opportunity to do so. There were at least 73 live participants, and over 160 live or asynchronous participants. More than 40 videos were posted to the YouTube channel for preview by the participants.
